_header: I am gracious and great God withouten beginning
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler notes ten stanzas added to end, TM 60.
_description: The York Plays — in various stanzaic patterns including 6-line stanzas (aaabab).

BLAdd35290.First Lines: I am gracyus and grete god with outyn begynnyngI am makere vnmade all mighte es in me…
BLAdd35290.Last Lines: …Tibi data potestas ande plenall influenceThou ert my sonne
BLAdd35290.Note:
MS refoliated; listed in Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943 as starting on f. 2; preceded by heading for first play, “The Barkers,” and two lines of Latin: “Ego Sum Alpha & O Vita via Veritas primus & nouissimus” (f. 4).

YorkCityAC104.First Lines:
Alas the woo þat we are wroghtHad neuer no men so mekyll
                    thowghtSens þat oure lord to deth was browghtWith Jewys
                    ffell…
YorkCityAC104.Last Lines: …And my blissyng I gyve you herAnd this menye
YorkCityAC104.Note:
Play 42, Scriveners, only; ‘Skryveners’ on outside cover
                    with names of players in left margin next to beginning of speeches.
